newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Court ruling renews takeover war over Hanwha - paper.
newsitem.headline: Court ruling renews takeover war over Hanwha - paper.

text.p: A South Korean court's ruling over the legality of privately placed convertible bonds issued by Hanwha Merchant Bank renewed a takeover battle in the bank, local newspapers reported on Wednesday.
The Chosun Ilbo reported the Seoul District High Court on Tuesday ruled that the convertible bonds privately placed by the company were illegal.

"The convertible bond issue was illegal because it abused the convertible bond system and infringed the rights of existing shareholders to underwrite new shares," the Chosun Ilbo quoted the verdict as reading.
Court officials were not available for comment.
The court was reviewing a lawsuit filed by Hanwha's second-largest shareholder, Park Eui-song, seeking to nullify the effect of the privately placed convertible bonds.
But the court rejected Park's demand that the effect of new shares already converted be scrapped, saying that accepting the demand could lead to a change in the management rights.
The Hanwha Group, the nation's ninth largest conglomerate, currently holds the largest stake of 18.89 percent in Hanwha Merchant Bank.
In January, Hanwha issued convertible bonds and privately placed them with "shareholders friendly to it".
An earlier court ruling favoured Hanwha's move.
On Tuesday, shares in Hanwha Merchant Bank rose 1,200 won to their daily limit of 16,400 on speculation that a renewed takeover battle in the company would boost its share prices.
The speculation was sparked by a statement released by Park that the court ruled in favour of him.
The Seoul stock market is closed on Wednesday for Buddha's Birthday, with trading resuming on Thursday.
